title: How will augmented reality change the world? - Quora

response.answer_text: Augmented Reality will not change the world, at least not in its current state. Augmented reality is a tool, and mostly a visualization tool.  In its current state, it is a novel tool, great for standing out and getting the short term attention of consumers.  At its current best, it gives additional visual data and cues-- think machine maintenance walk throughs and "what's around me". However, augmented reality will change the world when the hardware and the content catches up. Current major limitations in AR include batteries, processing power, sensors (cameras included), form factor (right now, we're stuck with mobile and this eye-wearable bandwagon), and of course content creation.  Many people confuse the data accumulation and representation (i.e 3d models) that are associated with current AR experiences to be part of the core AR technology. The AR tech itself, can generally be broken down into 1. Recognition2. Tracking3. RenderingThese three parts can be amazing and an AR experience will still seem useless, unless the information it is rendering is awesome. To make the transmittance of information awesome, we need hardware that is unobtrusive and responsive, and content to match.  Once we reach this point, we're talking about a world where anyone can look at anything and have the correct and useful information about it pop up. 1. Navigation: You have no sense of direction.  You have a map, but you don't know which way is north. AR will provide the navigation overlaid on the real world path you need to take  2. Maintenance/ Training: You're training to be a pilot. There are hundreds of buttons. AR helps you go through the buttons in the order you need to fly the plane-- you'll simply see it overlaid on the actual control panel.  3. Everyday information: You need to catch a bus and know the weather. Looking at a bus sign gives you the schedule and next arriving bus; and looking at the sky and asking for the weather gives you that information. Augmented reality at its best will change the way we look at things and gather data.
